Hi Jeff, 

it is better to have more species because this means that NEAT w=
ill 
cover a larger part of the search space simultaneously. But each 
spec=
ies must have a good number of members or otherwise there will be 
no enoug=
h individuals to mate with. You can calculate what will be the 
typical siz=
e of a species, assuming that each will get nearly equal 
fitness and that =
you use dynamic compatibility threshold (keeping 
species stable, not allow=
ing them to blow up in numbers). 

Peter

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Jeff=
 Clune <jclune@...> wrote:
>
> Thanks Ken and Matt. This is really good inf=
ormation, especially 
learning
> what rules of thumb you are operating by.
=
> 
> So, out of curiosity, if you do have the luxury of a larger 
populatio=
n size
> (presumably due to a problem with a quick fitness evaluation), whe=
re 
do you
> recommend investing? More species, or larger species?
> 
> Is =
it better to have 100 species of size 30, or 10 species of size 
300?
> 
> =
I am sure this too depends on the problem, but I would be interested 
in
> =
hearing what people have found tends to work (or, at least, what 
they tend=

> to do). 
> 
> 
> 
> 
> Cheers,
> Jeff Clune
> 
> Digital Evolution Lab, =
Michigan State University

> jclune@...

> > From: Kenneth Sta=
nley <kstanley@...>
> > Reply-To: "neat@yahoogroups.com" <neat@yahoogroups.=
com>
> > Date: Wed, 15 Oct 2008 17:33:38 -0000
> > To: "neat@...=
m" <neat@yahoogroups.com>
> > Subject: [neat] Re: Population sizes
> > 
> >=
 I haven't seen any explicit studies on population size in NEAT
> > specifi=
cally, but there have been such studies for genetic 
algorithms
> > in gene=
ral.  I think Kenneth De Jong's textbook, "Evolutionary
> > Computation: A =
Unified Perspective" examines it.
> > 
> > However, of course as people hav=
e pointed out in NEAT it's not 
just a
> > question of a healthy population=
 but of healthy species, since 
each
> > species is like its own little pop=
ulation.  In other words, the
> > species need enough internal diversity to=
 drive their own
> > explorations.  My own rule of thumb has been a minimum=
 of 15 
members
> > per species (on average) to keep them healthy.  I'm sur=
e 30 is 
even
> > safer.  
> > 
> > Another thing to note is that the popul=
ation size you need can 
vary
> > wildly by problem and it can be surprisin=
g.  For pole balancing, 
it
> > turns out that you can solve it fastest wit=
h a minuscule 
population of
> > size under 20 total (that's for the whole =
population!).   That is
> > because smaller populations are greedier (they =
concentrate 
resources
> > on a small part of the search space) and apparen=
tly pole balancing
> > benefits greatly from greedy search.  However, that =
is a specific
> > property of pole balancing and I would not expect it to c=
arry over 
to
> > more significant domains.  Surely in some domains having =
a 
population
> > over 1000 would lead to the most interesting results, if =
only you 
can
> > afford the luxury of the added computational cost of a la=
rge 
population.
> > 
> > ken
> > 
> > --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Jeff Cl=
une <jclune@> wrote:
> >> 
> >> That's funny. I heard the same thing about =
1000...that in ecology 
if a
> >> species gets under 1000 they really start=
 to worry about the
> > population. I
> >> don't think 30 will do it, but I=
 confess I have not read any
> > literature on
> >> it recently.
> >> 
> >>=
 Anyone else know?
> >> 
> >> Has anyone done any studies with NEAT on pop =
size to see what the
> > plot of
> >> pop size vs. fitness looks like?
> >>=
 
> >> 
> >> 
> >> 
> >> Cheers,
> >> Jeff Clune

on Lab, Michigan State University

> >>> 
> >>> I typically use around 150, but set th=
e target species to 5 
using a
> >>> changing compatability threshold.  Thi=
s gives a rough specie 
size of
> >>> 30. I read somewhere, and I can't rem=
ember where, some article 
about
> >>> Highland cattle having to have a bre=
eding population of 30 to 
make the
> >>> gene pool viable.
> >>> 
> >>> I =
guess its also a trade off with time also.  I am evolving 
Torcs
> >>> cont=
rollers for Julain Togelius' CIG 2008 commpetition.  Each
> >>> controller =
takes around 4 seconds to evaluate.  If I had a pop 
of over
> >>> 1000, it=
 would take a long time for my poor laptop to finish 
each
> > epoch.
> >>>=
 
> >>> Cheers
> >>> 
> >>> Matt
> >>>

Jeff Clune <jclune@> wrote:
> >>>> 
> >>>> Hello all-
> >>>> 
> >>>> What p=
opulation sizes to you typically use for NEAT?
> >>>> 
> >>>> We have done =
experiments in the Avida digital evolution 
platform that
> >>>> suggest th=
at below 1,000 org drift starts to play a role. But a 
lot
> >>> of the
> >=
>>> HyperNEAT papers use pop sizes of 150 or so. My guess is that 
the
> >>=
> diversity
> >>>> preserving measure ('speciation') and elitism help make =
smaller
> >>> populations
> >>>> effective, but I was wondering if anyone h=
as looked at the 
effects of
> >>>> population size in NEAT in an effort to=
 provide a *rough but 
general*
> >>>> suggestion as to how big to make the=
 populations in NEAT.
